Arts Reviews

Review: Pericles

Liam Mullally's weak bladder is the only thing holding back his enjoyment of The Upstage Theatre's production of Pericles

Review: Hamlet

Nathalie Taylor takes a look at DramaSoc's "solid" production of Hamlet

Review: Let the Right One In

Let the Right One In overcomes both the constraints of being a student production and the shadow of its masterful source material. Lara Medlam reviews

Review: Fahrenheit 451

DramaSoc's atmospheric production of Farenheit 451 is not to be missed. Naveen Morris reviews

Review: Ghost

Ghost takes its audience along for a ride. Jess Burgess reviews

Review: Spring Awakening

Drama Soc's latest play examines youth, sexuality, and the violence that often accompanies both. Rory Kelly reviews.

Review: The Phantom of the Opera

Despite being a little rough around the edges, The York Orchard's production of The Phantom of the Opera manages to entertain. Liam Mullally reviews

Review: Sweet Charity

CHMS excels itself in this week's star-studded offering. Sarah Horton reviews.

Review: Equus

Eliza Hunton marvels at DramaSoc's captivating production of Peter Shaffer's somewhat unnerving play.

Review: NSFW

Short but witty, NSFW opens important dialogues about the journalism industry. Deborah Lam reviews

Review: My Dinner with Andre

My Dinner with Andre is an accomplished production, but you might just be better off watching the film. Liam Mullally reviews

Review: Frozen

Frozen is in no way an easy watch, but if you can stomach its more disturbing content, it is a play that rewards. Liam Mullally reviews

Review: Jane Eyre

The National Theatre and Bristol Old Vic's co-produced production of Jane Eyre brings new life to the novel, without betraying the text. Emily McDonnell reviews

Review: Dick Whittington (and his meerkat)

Against the odds, Dick Whittington (and his meerkat) is a pantomime that delivers. Rhys Thompson reviews

Review: The Great Gatsby

In which Jack Richardson plays Jordan Baker's caddie, Jay Gatsby's business associate and Nick Caraway's confidant.

Review: Revenger's Tragedy

By James Bithell

TFTV's production of Revenger's Tragedy opens strongly but lacks some polish. Daniel Bowen reviews

Review: The Duchess of Malfi

By James Bithell

The Duchess of Malfi is 'a wonderful tense piece of period drama'. Daniel Bowen Reviews

Review: Wuthering Heights

By James Bithell

Despite some exceptional performances, DramaSoc's production of Wuthering heights is let down by its writing, finds Deborah Lam

Review: The Importance of Being Earnest

The Bunbury Company of Players present a unique interpretation of The Importance of Being Earnest. Jess Burgess reviews

Review: James Acaster: Represent

James Ancaster's Represent tour is both inventive and artfully performed, finds Louis Chilton

Review: After Midnight, Before Dawn

By James Bithell

Primitive, paranoid and possessed: DramaSoc's latest offering tackles witchcraft to electrifying effect. Ella Barker reviews

Review: Pornography

By James Bithell

Preoccupied with pain, sex, and isolation, Drama-Soc's latest production uses intimate character study and fearless performance to explore the darkest facets of human character.

Review: The Addams Family

By James Bithell

Pick Me Up Theatre's ghoulish adaptation of The Addams Family has the audience 'laughing, jumping and clapping'. Jess Burgess reviews

Review: Mancub

Primal instincts get a literal translation in Dramasoc's dazzling tale about a teenager who can turn into animals, not always to positive effect

Review: Henry V

By James Bithell

An adept and unsettling performance successfully combines both local and national commemorations of WWI and the Battle of Agincourt. Ella Barker reviews.

Review: Hamlet

By James Bithell

The National Theatre's latest production of Hamlet brings comedy, despair and grief, finds Elisabeth Myking

Review: The Last Five Years

By James Bithell

Nathalie Taylor finds The Last Five Years to be technically accomplished but lacking chemistry

Review: The Flick

Liam Mullally finds Dramasoc's charming production of The Flick to be both funny and melancholic

Review: Ruby Wax: Sane New World

A well poised and witty discussion of mental illness offers up a healthy dose of catharsis for both audience and comic. Rhys Thompson reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Jody Kamali

Part sketch, part theatre, part everything else, surrealist comic Kamali's Spectacular! is as delightful as it is bewildering
